questions.question: Which of the following mutations is responsible for hereditary haemochromatosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) HFE mutation Explanation: Hereditary hemochromatosis is due to an HFE gene mutation on chromosome 6p that causes excess iron absorption, leading to increased iron deposition. This results in the classic triad of cirrhosis , secondary diabetes mellitus , and bronze skin . Hereditary Hemochromatosis: Key laboratory findings: High ferritin, high serum iron and low TIBC. Liver biopsy: Golden-yellow hemosiderin granules in periportal hepatocytes that appear blue with a Prussian blue stain followed by a micronodular pattern of cirrhosis. Other findings: Dilated cardiomyopathy (m/c cardiac manifestation). Increased risk of hepatocellular carcinoma HJV (Hemojuvelin gene) causes juvenile hemochromatosis. Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder involving the ATP7B gene mutation (Option A) Gilbert syndrome , a harmless autosomal recessive disease, results from UGT1A1 gene mutation ( Option B) α 1-Antitrypsin deficiency is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to mutation in SERPINA1 gene leading to pulmonary emphysema and cirrhosis. Liver biopsy shows positive periodic acid-schiff stain and diastase resistance, highlighting the characteristic magenta cytoplasmic granules ( Option C)

questions.question: A 48-year-old man comes to the OPD with complaints of excessive thirst, excessive micturition, and increased hunger. He also states that his skin colour has changed in the past six months. He is icteric on examination, and his skin examination reveals findings similar to those in the image below. What is the most likely cause of the change in his skin colour?

options.A: Excessive melanin production due to adrenal insufficiency
options.B: Excessive deposition of melanin and iron in the skin
options.D: Excessive deposition of bilirubin in the skin

questions.explanation: patient has features of “ Bronze diabetes ” and liver dysfunction, which are typically seen in hemochromatosis. In Hemochromatosis, skin colour changes due to the deposition of excessive melanin >> iron in the skin. It is also known as "bronze diabetes" due to skin discolouration and associated pancreatic disease. The disease typically manifests after 20 g of stored iron has accumulated in the body. Organs affected Clinical features Liver Hepatomegaly, elevated liver enzymes, risk of HCC Pancreas Iron induced damage of beta cells - diabetes mellitus

questions.question: A 38-year-old female presents with fatigue, joint pain, and bronze skin pigmentation. Labs show a heterozygous mutation in the HFE gene. The histopathology image is shown below. Which of the following is the best screening test for this condition?

options.D: Genetic testing for the HFE gene

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Transferrin saturation Explanation: The diagnosis in this case is hemochromatosis . Transferrin saturation (TSAT) is the best screening test for hereditary hemochromatosis. TSAT measures the amount of iron bound to transferrin, reflecting the body's iron status. Elevated TSAT levels (>45-50%) suggest iron overload, which is a characteristic feature of hemochromatosis. Serum ferritin is a protein that stores iron in the body. However, while serum ferritin levels can be a useful indicator, they are not as specific as transferrin saturation (TSAT) for diagnosing hemochromatosis (Option A) . In hereditary hemochromatosis, LFTs may show abnormalities in advanced stages of the disease when iron overload has caused liver damage (e.g., elevated alanine transaminase or AST levels). However, LFTs are not specific screening tests for hemochromatosis (Option C) . Genetic testing for mutations in the HFE gene is the definitive diagnostic test for hereditary hemochromatosis (Option D) . Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 848

questions.question: A 25-year-old patient presents with a history of tremors, dysarthria, and personality changes. Serum ceruloplasmin levels were found to be low. Based on the image below, what ocular finding is associated with the underlying condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B ) Kayser-Fleischer rings Explanation: The image shows characteristic Kayser-Fleischer rings, a brownish-green discolouration in the cornea. These rings are associated with Wilson's disease, a genetic disorder involving copper metabolism. Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterised by impaired copper metabolism. It leads to copper accumulation primarily in the liver, brain, and other organs. Molecular genetic testing can identify mutations in the ATP7B gene, which is responsible for Wilson's disease. Clinical Features: Kayser-Fleischer Rings: These are characteristic brownish-green rings seen in the cornea due to copper deposition and are a hallmark feature of Wilson's disease. Serum copper is raised, while ceruloplasmin levels (a copper-binding protein) are decreased in Wilson's disease. Increased urinary copper excretion is a characteristic finding in Wilson's disease. Arcus senilis refers to a white or greyish ring around the cornea that is commonly seen in elderly individuals. It is caused by lipid deposits in the peripheral cornea and is generally considered a normal age-related change. ( Option A) Roth spots are retinal haemorrhages with a white or pale centre. Roth spots can be seen in various medical conditions, including bacterial endocarditis, leukemia, and diabetic retinopathy ( Option C) Horner's syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterised by a triad of eye and face symptoms. It includes ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid), miosis (constriction of the pupil), and anhidrosis (decreased sweating) on the affected side of the face ( Option D)

questions.question: Which of the following tests is the most specific for confirming the diagnosis of Wilson’s Disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Liver biopsy Explanation: Testing for Wilson's disease: Serum Ceruloplasmin (Option A) : Low levels are suggestive. 24-Hour Urinary Copper Excretion (Option B) : Increased in Wilson's disease Liver Function Tests (LFTs) (Option C): May show abnormalities. Kayser-Fleischer Rings Examination: Greenish-brown rings in the cornea. Genetic Testing: For ATP7B gene mutations, confirming diagnosis. Liver Biopsy (Option D) : Demonstrates hepatic copper accumulation (Most specific). Brain Imaging: MRI to assess neurological involvement. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 850

questions.question: Which special stain is commonly used to aid in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Rubeanic acid stain Explanation: The Rubeanic acid stain, also known as the Rhodanine stain, is commonly used to detect copper accumulation in liver tissue, particularly in the hepatocytes' cytoplasmic granules. This stain forms a distinctive brown-black color when it reacts with copper, aiding in the diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Rubeanic acid stain Stains the copper present within cytosolic granules of hepatocytes Oil red O stain Stains lipids (Option A) PAS stain Stains cells with high glycogen storage and also stains basement membrane (Option B) Prussian stain Stains hemosiderin / stored iron (Option D) Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 850

questions.question: A 50-year-old male presents with a history of chronic alcohol abuse and complains of right upper quadrant abdominal pain. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Laboratory investigations show elevated liver enzymes. Gross feature of the liver has a characteristic mottled appearance. Based on these findings and the image below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Nutmeg Liver Explanation: The patient's history of chronic alcohol abuse and the characteristic mottled appearance of the liver on imaging studies point towards Nutmeg Liver as the most likely diagnosis. Nutmeg liver, also known as congestive hepatopathy or passive hepatic congestion, is a condition characterized by a mottled appearance of the liver on imaging studies, resembling the cross-section of a nutmeg seed. questions.question: A 25-year-old female presents with fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Hepatocytes show globular inclusions which are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive. Her sibling died of the same liver condition a few years back. What is the primary function of the enzyme implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Inhibits neutrophil elastase Explanation: Alpha-1 antitrypsin ( α 1AT) is a serine protease inhibitor that plays a crucial role in inhibiting proteases, particularly neutrophil elastase. Alpha-1 Antitrypsin ( α 1AT ) deficiency is an autosomal recessive (AR) disorder with defective gene in Chromosome 14 - SERPINA1 gene In Alpha-1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (AATD), there is a deficiency or dysfunction of α 1AT, leading to decreased inhibition of neutrophil elastase . This results in uncontrolled protease activity , particularly neutrophil elastase, which can cause tissue damage, especially in the lungs and liver leading to pan-acinar emphysema and liver cirrhosis respectively Histopathology: The deficiency is characterised by the presence of round-to-oval cytoplasmic globular inclusions in hepatocytes, which are strongly periodic acid–Schiff (PAS)-positive and diastase-resistant.

questions.question: A 50-year-old patient with a history of recurrent biliary colic and cholangitis undergoes cholecystectomy. Multiple stones are retrieved intraoperatively, and an image of the stones is provided for reference. Which of the following is true about the type of pigmented stones likely seen in this patient?

options.D: Seen in infected large bile ducts

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Found in sterile bile Explanation: The provided image and clinical scenario depicting black-pigmented stones retrieved during cholecystectomy. Feature Cholesterol Stones Pigment Stones Predisposing conditions Seen in Western populations (Option A) , related to metabolic syndrome (Option B) , obesity and common in females Chronic hemolytic anaemia - Black stones Bacterial infections, parasitic infestations - Brown stones Composition >50% crystalline cholesterol monohydrate Calcium salts of unconjugated bilirubin and inorganic calcium salts Appearance Pale yellow, round to ovoid, granular, hard external surface Brown to black, soft, soap-like, spiculated or moulded contours Location Arise exclusively in the gallbladder Found in sterile gallbladder bile (black stones) or infected large bile ducts (brown stones) (Options C and D). Radiopacity Radiolucent (may become radiopaque with calcium carbonate) Black stones: 50-75% are radiopaque, Brown stones: Radiolucent

questions.question: All the following infections are associated with an increased risk of pigmented gallstones, except?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Aspergillus flavus Explanation: Aspergillus flavus plays a role in liver pathology primarily by producing aflatoxins. These are potent carcinogens that can cause liver damage, oxidative stress, and DNA mutations and ultimately increase the risk of hepatocellular carcinoma. However, they are not associated with an increased risk of gallstones. Options A, B, and C are associated with pigmented gallstones. Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 873, 874

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not a complication associated with gallstones?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Budd-Chiari syndrome Explanation: Complications of gallstones: Empyema Perforation Fistula formation Inflammation of the biliary tree (cholangitis) Obstructive cholestasis Pancreatitis (Option A) Gallstone ileus (Bouveret syndrome) (Option C) Increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma (Option B) Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 875

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents to the OPD with severe right upper quadrant pain radiating to the right shoulder, accompanied by nausea and vomiting. Clinical examination revealed a positive result for a clinical test shown in the image down below. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows an enlarged and tense gallbladder. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Subserosal haemorrhages Explanation: Based on the provided clinical vignette and positive murphy sign, the patient's presentation aligns with acute cholecystitis. The most likely finding associated with this condition is subserosal hemorrhages. Characteristics Acute cholecystitis Chronic cholecystitis Gall bladder appearance Thickened, tense, edematous, bright red or green-black Thickened, fibrotic, opaque grey-white Serosa Subserosal haemorrhages (Option D) , fibrinopurulent exudate Smooth serosa with Subserosal fibrosis (Option C) (subepithelial fibrosis also seen) Histology Erosion of mucosa, Edema, congestion, sparse

questions.question: Which condition is characterised by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Porcelain gallbladder Explanation: Porcelain gallbladder is characterized by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall. This condition is associated with chronic cholecystitis and may lead to an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma. Porcelain gallbladder (Option A) Hyalinizing cholecystitis (Option D) Characterized by extensive dystrophic calcification of the gallbladder wall. Characterized by complete replacement of the gallbladder wall and mucosa by dense fibrosis, with or without calcification. Associated with chronic cholecystitis and an increased risk of gallbladder carcinoma Reference: Robbins and Cotran, Pathological Basis of Disease, 10th Edition, Page 876
